parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>RV</title><part><name>type</name>=<value>command

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> arma1

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00

</value></part><part><name>game2</name>=<value> ofp

</value></part><part><name>version2</name>=<value> 1.99

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Strings

</value></part><part><name>gr2</name>=<value> Arrays

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Searches for an array element within array or a ANSI string within a ANSI string. Returns the 0 based index on success or -1 if not found.
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature </title><part><name index="1"/><value> Informative </value></part><part><name index="2"/><value> If Unicode support is desired, see [[forceUnicode]].</value></part></template>
<template lineStart="1"><title>Feature </title><part><name index="1"/><value> important </value></part><part><name index="2"/><value> Search is cASe-seNsItiVE!</value></part></template>

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> array [[find]] element

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> array: [[Array]] - array to search in

</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value> element: [[Anything]] - array element to find

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Number]] - 0 based position of the first array element that matches x, -1 if not found

</value></part><part><name>s2</name>=<value> string [[find]] substring <template><title>Since</title><part><name index="1"/><value>arma3</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.27.126674</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value>y</value></part></template>

</value></part><part><name>p21</name>=<value> string: [[String]] - string to search in

</value></part><part><name>p22</name>=<value> substring: [[String]] - substring to find

</value></part><part><name>r2</name>=<value> [[Number]] - 0 based position of the first sequence of characters that matches substring, -1 if not found
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>["Apples", "Oranges", "Pears"] [[find]] "Oranges"; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>returns 1</value></part></template></code>

</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>[1, [2], [<ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/></ext>[3]]] [[find]] [<ext><name>nowiki</name><attr/></ext>[3]]; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>returns 2 - does not work in OFP</value></part></template></code>

</value></part><part><name>x3</name>=<value> <code>[[if]] ([[magazines]] [[player]] [[find]] "Strela" != -1) [[then]] { [[hint]] "You've got Strela!"; };</code>

</value></part><part><name>x4</name>=<value> <code>[[hint]] [[str]] ("japa is the man!" [[find]] "the man!"); <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>returns 8</value></part></template></code>

</value></part><part><name>x5</name>=<value> <code>"abc" [[find]] ""; <template><title>cc</title><part><name index="1"/><value>returns 0</value></part></template></code>

</value></part><part><name>seealso</name>=<value> [[set]], [[resize]], [[reverse]], [[select]], [[in]], [[toArray]], [[toString]], [[forEach]], [[count]], [[pushBack]], [[pushBackUnique]], [[apply]], [[deleteAt]], [[deleteRange]], [[append]], [[sort]], [[param]], [[params]], [[arrayIntersect]], [[splitString]], [[joinString]], [[findIf]], [[forceUnicode]]
</value></part></template>

</comment><dl class="command_description">
<dd class="notedate">Posted on January 4, 2015 - 09:38 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Heeeere's Johnny!|Heeeere's Johnny!]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
Using '''[[nil]]''' on either side of '''find''' will make the whole statement return [[Nothing]]:
<code>_array = [1,2,[[nil]],4,5];
_result = _array '''find''' nil;
[[hintSilent]] [[str]] ([[isNil]] "_result"); //true
 
_result = nil '''find''' 1;
[[hintSilent]] [[str]] ([[isNil]] "_result"); //true</code>
</dd>

<dd class="notedate">Posted on April 10, 2015 - 17:01 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Kenoxite|Kenoxite]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
[[find]] doesn't work with multidimensional arrays in OFP/CWA. It will always returns -1.
</dd>

<dd class="notedate">Posted on May 17, 2016 - 14:21 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:BaerMitUmlaut|BaerMitUmlaut]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
This command is unreliable/broken when it comes to some non-ASCII characters (as of Arma 3 1.58):
<code>"abcßdef" find "c"
-> 2
"abcßdef" find "ß"
-> 3
"abcßdef" find "d"
-> 5</code>
</dd>

<dd class="notedate">Posted on July 7, 2016 10:56 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:Jtgibson|Jtgibson]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
Not quite unreliable, just unexpected! Strings are tracked in terms of bytes rather than in actual character positions; all strings are stored in UTF-8 format. In other words, the eszett character is in Unicode, which takes up two bytes rather than one as it is within the 128-255 range of Unicode.  (Similar results would be expected for the division symbol, the umlaut, accented e's, etc.)  Symbols that are particularly high in the Unicode range may take up three bytes, or even four for the truly exceptional characters, although Arma 3's default fonts are unlikely to render them.  This definitely complicates any script which assumes any printable character is a single byte, however, and unfortunately I'm not skilled enough with internationalisation to recommend any robust fix.
</dd>

<dd class="notedate">Posted on July 16, 2020 - 07:33 (UTC)</dd>
<dt class="note">[[User:R3vo|R3vo]]</dt>
<dd class="note">
If you want to return all occurences of a given string in a string use the following code. Thanks to ''sharp.'' for providing the code.<br>

<code>[[private]] _fnc_findStringsInString [[=]] 
{  
    [[params]] ["_string", "_search"]; 
    [[if]] (_string [[==]] "") [[exitWith]] {[]}; 
    [[private]] _searchLength = [[count]] _search; 
    [[private]] _return [[=]] []; 
    [[private]] _i [[=]] 0; 
    [[private]] _index [[=]] 0; 
    [[while]] {_index [[=]] _string [[find]] _search; _index [[!=]] -1} [[do]]
    { 
        _string [[=]] _string [[select]] [_index [[+]] _searchLength]; 
        _i [[=]] _i [[+]] _index [[+]] _searchLength; 
        _return [[pushBack]] _i [[-]] _searchLength; 
    }; 
    _return 
}; 
["Test,123,123,Test","Test"] [[call]] _fnc_findStringsInString;//Returns [0,13]</code>
</dd>
</dl>
